By executing this query, in any manner whatsoever, you agree to abide by these terms.  In some limited cases, domains that might appear as available in whois might not actually be available as they could be already registered and the whois not yet updated and/or they could be part of the Restricted list. In this cases, performing a check through your Registrar's (EPP check) will give you the actual status of the domain. Additionally, domains currently or previously used as extensions in 3rd level domains will not be available for registration in the 2nd level. For example, org.co, mil.co, edu.co, com.co, net.co, nom.co, arts.co, firm.co, info.co, int.co, web.co, rec.co, co.co.", '', 'NOTE: FAILURE TO LOCATE A RECORD IN THE WHOIS DATABASE IS NOT INDICATIVE OF THE AVAILABILITY OF A DOMAIN NAME. All domain names are subject to certain additional domain name registration rules. For details, please visit our site at www.cointernet.co <http://www.cointernet.co>.', '']}

thought: The WHOIS information suggests that the domain is not currently registered, which is consistent with the text extracted from the site claiming the domain is not suspended anymore. This could indicate that the domain was recently re-registered after being suspended, or it might be in the process of deletion. The registrant information is redacted for privacy, which is not unusual, but it does limit the information available to us. The domain status includes "pendingDelete," which suggests that the domain may soon be deleted or is awaiting deletion. This information alone is not enough to determine if the site is a scam, so I need to perform further analysis.

The hyperlinks extracted seem to point to legitimate sites for domain registration and legal information (go.co and cointernet.com.co). However, these links do not provide direct evidence regarding the legitimacy of the site in question. It is still unclear whether the site is a scam or not based on the current information. I should look for external information about the website, such as reviews or discussions on social platforms, to see if there are any reports of suspicious activity.

The browser add-on is available for Google Chrome and Microsoft Edge, and you can install it on as many devices as you want including those of your family and friends to ensure that everyone is protected. Click the link below to download the free ScamAdviser Browser Extension. Download Now Entire Review Webshop Review The Tranco ranking of this website is low. This can be considered low in relation to other websites from the website's country. If you think this website should be very popular, please invest additional time in researching the company as this is suspicious. For a smaller or starting website a low ranking can be considered normal. Technical Review We identified an SSL certificate meaning that the data shared between your browser and the website is encrypted and cannot be read by others. SSL certificates are always used by legit and safe websites. Unfortunately scammers increasingly also use SSL certificates so it is no guarantee that you are visiting a reliable website. Claim Website About this report The Popular Stories How to Recognize a Scam Website As the influence of the internet rises, so does the prevalence of online scams. There are fraudsters making all kinds of claims to trap victims online - from fake investment opportunities to online stores - and the internet allows them to operate from any part of the world with anonymity. The ability to spot online scams is an important skill to have as the virtual world is increasingly becoming a part of every facet of our lives. The below tips will help you identify the signs which can indicate that a website could be a scam.

This information is provided to you for informational purposes only and is designed to assist persons in determining contents of a domain name registration record in the .CO Internet registry database. .CO Internet makes this information available to you "as is" and does not guarantee its accuracy.', '', "By submitting a WHOIS query, you agree that you will use this data only for lawful purposes and that, under no circumstances will you use this data:  (1) to allow, enable, or otherwise support the transmission of mass unsolicited, commercial advertising or solicitations via direct mail, electronic mail, or by telephone; (2) in contravention of any applicable data and privacy protection laws; or (3) to enable high volume, automated,  electronic processes that apply to the registry (or its systems). Compilation, repackaging, dissemination, or other use of the WHOIS database in its entirety, or of a substantial portion thereof, is not allowed without .CO Internet's prior written permission. .CO Internet reserves the right to modify or change these conditions at any time without prior or subsequent notification of any kind. By executing this query, in any manner whatsoever, you agree to abide by these terms.  In some limited cases, domains that might appear as available in whois might not actually be available as they could be already registered and the whois not yet updated and/or they could be part of the Restricted list. In this cases, performing a check through your Registrar's (EPP check) will give you the actual status of the domain. Additionally, domains currently or previously used as extensions in 3rd level domains will not be available for registration in the 2nd level. For example, org.co, mil.co, edu.co, com.co, net.co, nom.co, arts.co, firm.co, info.co, int.co, web.co, rec.co, co.co.", '', 'NOTE: FAILURE TO LOCATE A RECORD IN THE WHOIS DATABASE IS NOT INDICATIVE OF THE AVAILABILITY OF A DOMAIN NAME. All domain names are subject to certain additional domain name registration rules. For details, please visit our site at www.cointernet.co <http://www.cointernet.co>.', '']}

thought: The text extracted from the website indicates that the domain had been suspended and now has been restored, but it does not provide any specific content that could be associated with a scam. However, the message about the domain suspension and asking the registrant to update their nameservers could be a red flag, as it may imply a lack of stability or legitimacy. I should check the domain information to see if there are any other signs of a scam.

The WHOIS information reveals that the domain is not currently registered and is pending deletion. The registrant's information is redacted for privacy, but the registrant is listed as being from Russia, which in itself is not necessarily a red flag, but it could be noteworthy depending on other factors. The domain status being "clientTransferProhibited" and "pendingDelete" indicates that the domain may have had issues or is in the process of being removed. This could imply that the website's operation is not stable or legitimate. Given the lack of concrete content on the website and the domain's status, the next step would be to check if there's any public sentiment or information about the website being a scam.
